title: 110_s1891
content: IMMUNITY FOR REPORTS OF SUSPECTED TERRORIST ACTIVITY OR SUSPICIOUS BEHAVIOR AND RESPONSE. Immunity is granted to individuals who report suspected terrorist activity or suspicious behavior in good faith and based on reasonable suspicion. They are protected from civil liability under any law for making such reports. However, this immunity does not apply if the report is knowingly false or made with reckless disregard for the truth. Additionally, immunity is also provided for the response to these reports. Authorized officials who observe or receive reports of covered activity and respond in good faith are granted qualified immunity from civil liability. This immunity does not apply if the report is knowingly false or made with reckless disregard for the truth. Authorized officials not entitled to qualified immunity are immune from civil liability if they take reasonable action in good faith to respond to reported activity. This immunity does not affect their ability to assert any other available defense, privilege, or immunity. In this section, authorized officials are immune from civil liability if they take reasonable action in good faith. This immunity does not affect their ability to assert any defense, privilege, or immunity available. If found immune, they can recover all reasonable costs and attorney fees from the plaintiff. The term "covered activity" refers to individuals involved in security responsibilities for passenger transportation systems, including employees of relevant government departments and law enforcement officers. The term "covered activity" includes any suspicious transaction, activity, or occurrence involving a passenger transportation system or vehicle indicating potential law violations related to threats to passenger safety, security, or terrorism. The term "passenger transportation" includes public transportation, over-the-road bus transportation, school bus transportation, intercity passenger rail transportation, and transportation of passenger vessels. The term "passenger transportation system" includes various modes of transportation such as passenger vessels, waterborne transportation services, and air transportation for passengers. The term "passenger transportation system" refers to entities providing passenger transportation using vehicles and related infrastructure. The term "vehicle" is defined as per section 1992(16) of title 18, United States Code. This section will be effective immediately upon enactment of the Act and applies to activities and claims from that date onwards.
